title: 106_hr5530
content: The Act titled "Chapter 12 Extension and Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 2000" extends Chapter 12 of Title 11 of the United States Code until July 1, 2001. It also amends certain dates in previous laws related to bankruptcy. Additionally, the Act addresses the appointment of bankruptcy judgeships. The Chapter 12 Extension and Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 2000 extends Chapter 12 of Title 11 of the United States Code until July 1, 2001. It also amends certain dates in previous laws related to bankruptcy and addresses the appointment of additional bankruptcy judges in various districts. The Chapter 12 Extension and Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 2000 extends Chapter 12 of Title 11 of the United States Code until July 1, 2001. It also addresses the appointment of additional bankruptcy judges in various districts, including Michigan, Mississippi, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, and Pennsylvania. The Chapter 12 Extension and Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 2000 extends Chapter 12 of Title 11 of the United States Code until July 1, 2001. It also addresses the appointment of additional bankruptcy judges in various districts, including Pennsylvania, Puerto Rico, Tennessee, and Virginia. Vacancies in the office of a bankruptcy judge in specified districts shall not be filled under certain conditions. The temporary office of bankruptcy judges in certain districts is extended until a vacancy occurs due to death, retirement, resignation, or removal of a judge. The extensions vary based on the district and the date specified in the Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 1992. The temporary office of bankruptcy judges in specific districts is extended for varying periods, ranging from 8 to 10 years after specific dates. Other provisions of the Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 1992 continue to apply, except as specified. Technical amendments are made to section 152(a) of title 28, United States Code. The Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 1992 is amended to change the appointment process for bankruptcy judges in specific districts. The number of judges for the middle district of Georgia is increased from 2 to 3, and the collective item for the middle and southern districts of Georgia is adjusted.
